terms.definition: A for-profit financial institution that accepts deposits, offers checking and savings accounts, and provides loans.
terms.example: Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, local community banks

terms.definition: A not-for-profit cooperative financial institution owned by its members, offering similar services to banks.
terms.example: Navy Federal, State Employees CU, school or employer-based credit unions

terms.definition: A company that provides policies to protect against financial loss from unforeseen events.
terms.example: Health, auto, home/renters, life, disability insurance

terms.definition: A company that manages investment portfolios to help clients grow wealth through securities.
terms.example: IRAs, brokerage accounts, mutual funds, financial planning

paragraphs: Checking, savings, loans, credit cards. FDIC insured up to $250,000. Nationwide networks.
Similar services to banks with lower fees, better rates. NCUA insured up to $250,000.
Protection against financial loss from unforeseen events. Health, auto, home, life coverage.
Specialize in home loans and real estate financing. May offer specialized loan products.
Manage investments to help grow wealth. Offer IRAs, brokerage accounts, financial planning.
Facilitate buying and selling of stocks and securities. Full-service or discount options.

leftPanel.title: Federal Deposit Insurance
paragraphs: Both banks and credit unions offer deposit insurance that protects your money if the institution fails.
FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation) insures bank deposits.
NCUA (National Credit Union Administration) insures credit union deposits.
Both provide the same protection level‚Äîchoose based on other factors like fees and service.

layoutData.title: Match Providers to Your Financial Needs
paragraphs: Different financial needs require different service providers. Understanding what each offers helps you make the best choice for your situation.
bulletPoints: Daily banking (checking/savings): Banks or credit unions based on fees and convenience
Buying a home: Mortgage companies, banks, or credit unions for competitive loan rates
Investing for retirement: Investment firms with low-fee index funds or retirement accounts
Protecting your assets: Insurance companies for auto, health, home coverage
Trading stocks: Brokerage firms‚Äîfull-service for advice, discount for DIY
Starting a business: Banks with business services and lending programs

leftPanel.title: What to Evaluate
paragraphs: When selecting a financial service provider, consider these key factors:
Fees: Monthly maintenance, ATM fees, overdraft charges, transaction fees.
Interest Rates: Savings APY, loan rates, credit card rates.
Convenience: Branch locations, ATM network, mobile app quality.
Services: Does the provider offer what you need now and in the future?

layoutData.title: Financial Impact Over Time
paragraphs: Choosing the right financial service provider can save you thousands of dollars over your lifetime and help you reach your financial goals faster.
bulletPoints: Lower fees = More money stays in your pocket each month
Better interest rates = Your savings grow faster, loans cost less
Right services = You can manage money more efficiently
Convenient access = You stay on top of your finances easily
Good customer service = Problems get resolved quickly
Security features = Your money and identity stay protected

leftPanel.title: Traditional vs. Online Banking
paragraphs: Today's financial landscape includes both traditional brick-and-mortar institutions and online-only options.
Traditional Banks/Credit Unions: In-person service, local branches, face-to-face help.
Online Banks: Higher interest rates, lower fees, 24/7 access, but no physical branches.
Many people use a combination‚Äîan online bank for savings and a local institution for daily banking.
